body.value:
My dear Sir

Your kindness in forwarding the Feby No. of the Oc-cident claims my grateful thanks. Its contents at once show the lamentable state of disunion upon matters in connection with religion amongst Israelites in America, and sufficiently exhibit the impracticability of your inserting my communication, up to this time. There may be other reasons wherefore you think it improper. In the absence of a special explanation, I can only, and but imperfectly, infer your views from the course of proceedings. Had the Occident contained an indication of liberty to proceed in addressing your readers, this letter would, agreeably to intimation, have inclosed a year's subscription, as I would not remain under obligation for worldly favour, when it is avoidable. But since the seeking of your assistance is, or ought to be, solely in obedience to spiritual mandates which I dare not disregard, I must learn in some way, if possible, to what extent your good will or good opinion towards my business may be counted upon. To purchase and pay for the Occident while containing nothing in this regard, would make me no wiser in that respect. If you insert or discuss my letters, I can then learn your views on them; if you are so liberal as to continued the transmission of the Oc-cident without expectation of payment, it must be from some special consideration; and if you withdraw it, while aware how necessary it is to me to learn by its medium the prospect of the proposed assembly. I shall be nonetheless enabled to appreciate your estimation in my behalf. I am the more anxious to learn, from practical demonstration, your judgment concerning me because the very extraordinary situation in which I am placed overwhelms my weak and unsettled mind with the dread of misconceiving my duty. By carefully comparing ideas with the differently affected yet interested and able to discover the truth, I may test the soundness of conceptions, which, without

some corroboration, must incur distrust. The inclosed $1.00 I beg you to accept on act. Of some No's of the O. formerly sent me at New York; or if you would decline it on that ground, let it be to defray postage which may occur.

One would think that, while so desirous of bringing my views before some authority in Israel, I should greatly rejoice in the prospect of an Assembly and their doings, as now before us; but reflection upon the issue of my formal application to the Beth Din in New York as I reported it to you, teaches me to expect little from any body of men who may be actuated by a dread of compromising their character for wisdom. Yet as our excellent friend Mr. Noot, Dr. Salomon and another passed a resolution that my representations were worthy of attention and ought to be investigated & reported on by two or more persons of the first distinction for learning devotion, character and understanding, I must not fail, if the venerable in Israel come together, to apply for the relection of a suitable committee, who after free and full communication, shall formally declare their views of the matter submitted to their consideration. If you would do me the greatest kindness, if you would become nobly instrumental in relieving the deepest anxieties of a mind that seeks to ascertain its duties in order to their discharge, you have but to forward by every means in your power my honest aim to bring the teachings of this extraordinary state of mind fairly and fully before the Jewish public for their consideration To my private desires, it would seem to be of little importance how men should entertain these disclosures provided the decision could be final. What makes me anxious is that whilst my thoughts are absorbed as they are and must be for the present, my wife and children are suffering for the want of attention which is their due, and which I cannot give them, as my faculties are insufficient under such a distraction. It appears that I must either become an active, however humble, servant of Israel, or, obtaining some conscientious satisfaction that will

authorize the withdrawal of my attention from the subject, devote the more energy to pursuits of a private nature. Could I but learn by a reasonable decision of the judgments of others upon these uncommon views, that they must pass for either erroneous or impracticable, gladly would I hail the liberty to apply to the cares labours and pleasures of my family and farm; gladly would I strive to join in the common and selfish pursuits of life: but while the best and soundest with whom I am enabled to converse, approve and even reverence my views, while those who censure are evidently inconsiderate in their examinations, while it is not only what has been manifested to an excited perception; but a calm examination of all current events of every sort leads to a like conclusion,—and while, to my utter amazement, the whole seems indicated in the prophecies of old, how can I doubt the evidence that presents itself to one purpose in so many different ways, when that purpose is but the establishment of a government recognizing, what sound sense requires, as a leading principle, the accountability of man to his maker?

I do not appeal to you for the sake of Israel, for you are sufficiently bound already to that consideration. I plead not for the good of mankind in general, for you comprehend as well as I the connection between the Restoration and the spread of intelligence, uprightness and peace. But as the Lord so orders that even in our highest aims we are influenced more or less by private regards; as He kindly grants the grateful stimulus of selfish satisfaction in our most sacred aspirations; and as we are humble men, of limited capacities, yet generous and sympathetic feelings; I will endeavour to elicit your sensibilities in my favour by appealing to your knowledge as a spiritual teacher and your heart as my brother man, in regard to my private position as a religious individual. I have

two children, sweet little girls, the eldest but two years of age, whom I would bring up in the knowledge and fear of the Lord. I am an Israelite in faith, if I know what it is to be an Israelite— namely, to live under a perfect sense of accountability to God, aiming in all things to do that which is right in His view; therefore necessarily adopting the high wisdom of inspiration in the formation of rules of conduct, and devoutly seeking self-improvement and the general good in associating with others disposed to worship and serve God in purity and truth. I would say with pious Joshua “as for me and my house, we will serve the Lord.”— but how? Shall I take my family to a Christian Church to hear that belief in absurdity is the vital condition of happiness hereafter. Shall we cultivate ignorance, and avoid participating in any established form of worship—to the effect that ? be heaped upon my innocents as being trained to error and infidelity? Or shall I crave admission from a Jewish congregation, to join in prayer for the advent of a Messiah, instead of returning thanks for the appointment of a special and most distinguished service— shall I enter such a congregation on condition of allegiance to all the existing Laws and customs, when I do not intend to obey them, and the very perception which makes me desire religious association, also assures me that many of those usages and institutions are now needless, some of them wrong, and that it is my especial calling to be humbly instrumental in their reform? Which shall I adopt, of these erroneous courses? Or rather what can I do but prayerfully trust in the Divine Goodness to relieve my perplexities in due time, and strive by every means to bring my views to be compared with those of others whose superior attainments entitle them to respect and confidence, while their vital wants, the proper longing of their souls, must stimulate them to discover and approve and establish the truth if truth it be, which I have to disclose

2

I can see no other course to be right; and therefore do I thus beseech assistance. For some half year more, according to a remarkable impression, must I remain in this uncertainty and trouble: if by that time there be not a clearing up of difficulties I shall have cause to respect a radical error in these sublime perceptions.

You once wrote me the story of Shaman and Hillel and one who would become a Jew with the condition of being made High Priest. The case is no parallel to mine; I desire no distinction—far less the accountability of power. I have lived forty years without at any time being led by political ambition or religious zeal. True heroes, in my view, are those who, keeping within their means, devoutly apply themselves to the common duties of life. What devotion I have exercised may have been far surpassed in the experience of many religious minds amongst us. It is prophecy a startling glimpse of the natural course of events, and their causes, showing the unfailing means established for the production of good, which it only devolves upon men to observe and employ, that this impels me to so strange a course. What should I care for worldly appearances? What is it to me if my conduct seem unaccountable and absurd to those who know not its motives? I must only hasten to bring matters to a crisis, to attain facilities for efficient action, or freedom to forbear from futile endeavours. Will you not help me? Do I ask more than naturally pertains between man and man? You admit that the developments of the day indicate the present as a fit time for rising in behalf of Israel. Let it then be decided whether I may lawfully and properly undertake to act in this good cause in conjunction with the chosen servants of the most High. If you say that I am not a Jew, let me ask, was Abraham other, in that respect, than I am? Or did Moses submit to a string of rabbinical exactions? Supposing he had, it would be no rule for me. The useless part of these observances must be done away. The general forms of Jewish worship are as grand in effect as venerable from antiquity. But many special institutions which were founded in good reason from the exigency of circumstances, have now no effect but a detrimental in

fluence. Long have the people groaned under these absurd incumbrances; and what is worse, forsaken the faith of their fathers, to escape form such annoying accomplishments. In assisting to retain these evils, you become answerable for their natural consequences. It needs but to prune away such exhausting, useless and unsightly branches—it needs but to exhibit the pure principles of religious faith under a rational and modest form, and the tree of righteousness will flourish, take root in the earth, unfold its blossoms to the world, give fragrance to the airs of heaven, and yield reproductive fruit spreading abroad for the delight and shade and comfort of regenerate man. The pure Jewish faith, the simple belief in omnipresent Deity, to whom we are strictly accountable, must become the religion of the world, not because it is written that the Lord declared so by His prophet not because it bears a fascinating show to the imagination for it does not, but because it is the truth, and men are becoming sufficiently enlightened and considerate to distinguish simple truth from seductive falsehood. Let the Jew once stand a free man in his own country, and the brawling nations will let fall their weapons in astonishment, acknowledge in their heart the truth of revelation, and incline to turn from the errors of their ways. Then may peace and reason and kindness prevail; for men, become more reflective, will see it for their interests to cultivate good dispositions. The best minds among gentiles will associate themselves with the already established Jews. Different races will thus intermingle without violence to law or custom. By this means a large portion of subsequent generations will be born under the ameliorating influence of those natural laws hereby increase of vigor is given to cross breeds. The ancient blood of Israel serving as a basis, a foreign admixture to a certain extent, will benefit the race, promoting the development of its energies, and marking the Jews, as a people,

with such physical and mental superiority, as must inevitably render them masters amongst mankind. The use they will make of power, must depend, in a great measure, upon the purity of their religious principles: and it therefore devolves the more fearfully upon us, if it please God to employ our weak hands in this His good work, to aim at the highest perfection in whatever rules and practices we may ? to establish.

It is observable from the records of history, as well as researches into nature, that the chief means whereby a race arrives at a high standard of perfection is the copulation of parentage bringing together somewhat dissimilar constitutions: yet, when one of the parties is highly cultivated, extreme opposition does not answer the purpose: thus the refined white and the barbarous negro or Indian cannot be intermixture bring improvement to the superior; and the effect is questionable even upon the inferior race. In a mind of much refinement is established a deep repugnance to the coarseness of ignorance and vulgarity; for it is decreed that when such excellence is once attained, it ought not to be thrown away: yet the two sexes are established, that, by continental intermixture of different constitutions, offspring may arise inheriting the general characteristics, which it is our business to establish in ourselves, of both parents; and not the particular defects which may be beyond our control, of either. Intermarriages therefore are predicated upon a positive, though not extreme, dissimilarity of constitution in the parties, while they are as necessarily influence by similarity of sentiments, habits and pursuits. It is then plain that the restored Jews, together with those noble

-ble-minded from other nations, who will dare to cast off the fetters of error and prejudice, must operate under every beneficial influence to produce the most powerful and highly gifted race of which we can conceive, precisely in accord-ance with undeviating and well known laws of nature. There is no record of a people becoming, either on the whole or at any particular time, great and powerful in all respects, whose physical excellence is not to be traced directly to the inter-mingling of different races or dissimilar tribes. Thus, under ordinary circumstances, a conquest? however lamentable to the humbled people becomes the means, under God, of health and blessing to posterity. If a nation could but comprehend their duty, if a government would only provide, by ade-quate and strictly natural means; for the development of every inherent energy of man, and for preserving the excellence of the race when once attained, that people could never be subdued; for, granting by way of argument, the existence of abler nations, their ability would abundantly supply their wants by easier and more profitable measures than war against the unoffending, who would be supported by a sense of justice, and ruled by a regard for the most High, that would require conquest and extermination to be made synonimous terms. Even the corrupted Jews of old were but beaten and dispersed, and not subdued like other nations, to resign their peculiar laws and coalesce with the victors. They were conquered as men—not as Jews. Persecution, in its ut-most violence could only cripple, but never tame their true spirit of adoration. It has still angered upon earth and groaned in agony unto the Lord of hosts,—and lo! he com--eth to relieve. Most faithfully yours—

George Barnard

Sherbrooke C. E. 12th February 5609.
